hints.content: Start by understanding what it means for a number to be odd. A number is odd if it is not divisible by 2. You can check this using the modulus operator: `num % 2 != 0`.
Think about how you might traverse the array. You will likely need to iterate through the elements of the array to check for consecutive odd numbers.
Consider using a loop to go through each element of the array. As you check each number, keep track of how many consecutive odd numbers you've encountered.
You can use a counter to count the number of consecutive odd numbers. Reset this counter to zero whenever you encounter an even number.
What happens if you reach the end of the array without finding three consecutive odd numbers? Make sure to handle the end of the array correctly in your logic.
Remember to check the length of the array. If the array has fewer than 3 elements, you can immediately return false, as it's impossible to have three consecutive odds.
As you implement your solution, consider edge cases such as arrays with all even numbers or arrays that are very short. These cases should be handled gracefully.
When you find an odd number, increment your counter. If you find a second consecutive odd number, increment again. If you find a third, you can return true immediately.
If you finish iterating through the array without finding three consecutive odd numbers, make sure your function returns false. This is an important part of the logic.
Here's a near-solution hint: As you loop through the array, check if the current number and the next two numbers are odd. If they are, return true. Otherwise, continue checking.

questionNotes: Return true if there are three consecutive odd numbers, otherwise return false.
